rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: An Offer/Answer Model with Session Description Protocol (SDP)***RFC: 3264***Draft name: draft-ietf-mmusic-sdp-offer-answer***Abstract: This document defines a mechanism by which two entities can make use of the Session Description Protocol (SDP) to arrive at a common view of a multimedia session between them. In the model, one participant offers the other a description of the desired session from their perspective, and the other participant answers with the desired session from their perspective. This offer/answer model is most useful in unicast sessions where information from both participants is needed for the complete view of the session. The offer/answer model is used by protocols like the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP). [STANDARDS-TRACK]***Group: Multiparty Multimedia Session Control***Area: Applications and Real-Time Area***Creation: 01/31/2002***Publish: 07/03/2002")

svg.text: An Offer/Answer Model with Session Description Protocol (SDP)

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Internet Official Protocol Standards***RFC: 5000***Draft name: rfc5000***Abstract: This document is published by the RFC Editor to provide a summary of the current standards protocols (as of 18 February 2008). It lists those official protocol standards, Best Current Practice, and Experimental RFCs that have not been obsoleted; it is not a complete index to the RFC series. Newly published RFCs and RFCs whose status has changed are starred.***Group: Individual Submissions***Area: General Area***Creation: 05/08/2008***Publish: 05/08/2008")

ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels***RFC: 2119***Draft name: draft-bradner-key-words***Abstract: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.***Group: Individual Submissions***Area: General Area***Creation: 09/02/1996***Publish: 03/01/1997")

svg.text: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Re-INVITE Handling in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)***RFC: None***Draft name: draft-camarillo-sipping-reinvite***Abstract: In this document, we clarify the handling of re-INVITEs in SIP. Weclarify in which situations a UAS (User Agent Server) should generatea success response and in which situations a UAS should generate anerror response to a re-INVITE. Additionally, we clarify issuesrelated to target refresh requests.***Group: Individual Submissions***Area: General Area***Creation: 03/03/2009***Publish: None")

svg.text: Re-INVITE Handling in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Use of the SIP Preconditions Framework for Media Privacy***RFC: None***Draft name: draft-shacham-sip-media-privacy***Abstract: Recording of a conversation presents a possible breach of privacy. This document presents a use of the SIP Preconditions Framework to negotiate the recording guidelines for the session. One party may assert either their desire to record or their restriction of the other party's recording. In order to establish the session, the other party must respond that it agrees to the conditions. While this does not have the power to limit the physical recording by the user on the end system, it provides evidence of the expressed wishes of one party and the agreement of the other.***Group: Individual Submissions***Area: General Area***Creation: 06/28/2005***Publish: None")

svg.text: Use of the SIP Preconditions Framework for Media Privacy

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Rights Contributors Provide to the IETF Trust***RFC: 5378***Draft name: draft-ietf-ipr-3978-incoming***Abstract: The IETF policies about rights in Contributions to the IETF are designed to ensure that such Contributions can be made available to the IETF and Internet communities while permitting the authors to retain as many rights as possible. This memo details the IETF policies on rights in Contributions to the IETF. It also describes the objectives that the policies are designed to meet. This memo obsoletes RFCs 3978 and 4748 and, with BCP 79 and RFC 5377, replaces Section 10 of RFC 2026. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.***Group: Intellectual Property Rights***Area: General Area***Creation: 03/01/2007***Publish: 11/10/2008")

svg.text: Rights Contributors Provide to the IETF Trust

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Best Current Practices for Third Party Call Control (3pcc) in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)***RFC: 3725***Draft name: draft-ietf-sipping-3pcc***Abstract: Third party call control refers to the ability of one entity to create a call in which communication is actually between other parties. Third party call control is possible using the mechanisms specified within the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP). However, there are several possible approaches, each with different benefits and drawbacks. This document discusses best current practices for the usage of SIP for third party call control. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.***Group: Session Initiation Proposal Investigation***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 05/10/2002***Publish: 04/13/2004")

svg.text: Best Current Practices for Third Party Call Control (3pcc) in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: A Hitchhiker's Guide to the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)***RFC: 5411***Draft name: draft-ietf-sip-hitchhikers-guide***Abstract: The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is the subject of numerous specifications that have been produced by the IETF. It can be difficult to locate the right document, or even to determine the set of Request for Comments (RFC) about SIP. This specification serves as a guide to the SIP RFC series. It lists a current snapshot of the specifications under the SIP umbrella, briefly summarizes each, and groups them into categories. This memo provides information for the Internet community.***Group: Session Initiation Protocol***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 06/21/2006***Publish: 02/04/2009")

svg.text: A Hitchhiker's Guide to the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Integration of Resource Management and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)***RFC: 3312***Draft name: draft-ietf-sip-manyfolks-resource***Abstract: This document defines a generic framework for preconditions which isextensible through IANA registration. This document also discusseshow network quality of service can be made a precondition toestablishment of sessions initiated by the Session InitiationProtocol (SIP). These preconditions require that the participantreserve network resources before continuing with the session. We donot define new quality of service reservation mechanisms; thesepreconditions simply require a participant to use existing resourcereservation mechanisms before beginning the session***Group: Session Initiation Protocol***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 11/10/2000***Publish: 10/17/2002")

svg.text: Integration of Resource Management and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: SIP: Session Initiation Protocol***RFC: 3261***Draft name: draft-ietf-sip-rfc2543bis***Abstract: This document describes Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), an application-layer control (signaling) protocol for creating, modifying, and terminating sessions with one or more participants. These sessions include Internet telephone calls, multimedia distribution, and multimedia conferences. [STANDARDS-TRACK]***Group: Session Initiation Protocol***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 07/17/2000***Publish: 07/03/2002")

ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) UPDATE Method***RFC: 3311***Draft name: draft-ietf-sip-update***Abstract: This specification defines the new UPDATE method for the SessionInitiation Protocol (SIP). UPDATE allows a client to updateparameters of a session (such as the set of media streams and theircodecs) but has no impact on the state of a dialog. In that sense, itis like a re-INVITE, but can be sent before the initial INVITE hascompleted. This makes it very useful for updating session parameterswithin early dialogs.***Group: Session Initiation Protocol***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 02/18/2002***Publish: 10/15/2002")

svg.text: The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) UPDATE Method

rect.onmousemove: ShowTooltip(evt, "Title: Update to the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) Preconditions Framework***RFC: 4032***Draft name: draft-ietf-sip-rfc3312-update***Abstract: This document updates RFC 3312, which defines the framework for preconditions in SIP. We provide guidelines for authors of new precondition types and describe how to use SIP preconditions in situations that involve session mobility. [STANDARDS-TRACK]***Group: Session Initiation Protocol***Area: Real-time Applications and Infrastructure Area***Creation: 11/21/2003***Publish: 03/11/2005")

svg.text: Update to the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) Preconditions Framework
